side scan sonar (sss): A method of waterbody surveying that utilizes electromagnetic signals to create high-resolution, two-dimensional maps of the seafloor, enabling the identification of subtle changes in underwater terrain and substrate characteristics, which can have a significant impact on the distribution and habitat suitability of aquatic species.

A underwater surveying technique that uses a combination of echoes and sonar waves to create high-resolution maps of the seafloor, revealing subtle changes in substrate and near-bottom flow that can influence the distribution of aquatic invasive species.

A remotely operated mapping tool that uses emitted sound waves to produce detailed images of the seafloor, allowing researchers to identify complex patterns of underwater habitats and their associations with aquatic organisms, particularly invasive species.

A sensing technology that produces a detailed, two-dimensional visual representation of the seafloor or riverbed, allowing for the detection of subtle variations in the underwater landscape that can inform assessments of the spatial distribution of aquatic organisms.
acoustic doppler: A technology used to measure water currents by detecting the subtle changes in sound waves as they bounce off particles, allowing scientists to gain valuable insights into the dynamic flow of aquatic environments and the habitats that aquatic species like Dreissena call home.

multibeam sonars (mb): A underwater mapping tool that emits acoustic pulses and records the returning signals to create a three-dimensional image of the seafloor, providing valuable information on waterbody topography and habitat features that can be crucial for determining the presence and distribution of invasive species.

Advanced underwater scanning technology that uses emitted sound waves to map and visualize the seafloor, providing detailed, three-dimensional representations of waterbody habitats and substrate characteristics.
